li.p: Linear functions form a two-parameter family, f (x) = b + mx.
The initial value of a linear function and the y-intercept of its graph are given by b. The rate of change of the function and the slope of its graph are given by m.
The slope-intercept form, y = b + mx, is useful when we know the initial value and the rate of change.
The point-slope form, y = y_1 + m(x - x_1), is useful when we know the rate of change and one point on the line.
